 I will respond to this one as it seems to be the best actual argument. The majority have a right to vote on such things. It is simply the way the system is set up. There are checks and balances in place such as the court systems to challenge those things. The legislature is not supposed to override the will of the people. Just because you disagree with them does not mean that you get to decide what they do. Just like them disagreeing with you does not mean they should get to decide what you do. That is why the checks and balances exist. My arguement is not with the content. My ONLY argument is that saying that they should not be allowed to vote on civil rights issues is, on its face, ridiculous. Voting is the greatest privelege we have in the USA. To prevent someone from voting one must be convicted of a felony. While some may consider what they wanted to vote on a felony, it is not and therefore the vote should, rightfully, be allowed. With the consequences of the vote being reviewed within the system of checks and balances that exist.
 
 Most folks here have personalized the issue and lost sight of the big picture.
 
 Huck

 Let me give you an example of people voting on civil liberties, and the Supreme Court of the United States striking the measure down as unconstitutional. It happened in 1996 in the case of Romer v. Evans. Citizens in Colorado had put a referendum question on the ballot calling for a state constitutional amendment banning any and all legislation in the state to protect people from discrimination based on sexual orientation. Voters approved this Colorado state constitutional amendment. The U.S. Supreme Court heard a challenge to the amendment and ruled that the state constitutional amendment violated the equal protection clause of the 14th amendment to the U.S. constitution. The Supreme Court ruled that the state constitutional amendment lacked even a rational basis and was spurred only by animus against gay people. The amendment, said the Supreme Court, denied gay people the equal protection of the laws and therefore was struck down. 
 
 This was a case in which the people in a state voted to deny gay people the equal protection of the laws, and the Supreme Court ruled that they cannot do that. The only way they could do that would be by pushing through an amendment to the U.S. constitution, which is not easy to do.

 Incorrect. The VOTE was not unconstitutional. Merely the wording of the law. The VOTE was perfectly constitutional. 
 
 That is my point precisely. It is not that the issue is one that SHOULD be supported. Rather it is that the ability to VOTE should be supported. The system of checks and balances (namely the courts) is where the law is determined to be unconstitutional or not. They may yet come up with one that passes constitutional muster. I do not know. My argument is that the removal of the vote from an initiative of the people by a legislated body is outside of the checks and balances and is in itself unconstitutional.
 
 Going through the effort is intended so that the voice of the people is heard. It is part of the system of checks and balances on the government. WE the people have a right to be heard, even if our idea is unpopular or even if the legislature does not like it.
 
 Huck

 I agree with the part of your argument in which you say that it was the law itself that was unconstitutional in Colorado, not the process of voting. I disagree with your argument that the removal of a vote from an initiative of the people by a legislative body is unconstitutional. In the case of the same-sex marriage issue in Massachusetts, which is what I think you are referring to here, the constitution of Massachusetts requires that a proposed constitutional amendment receive a certain number of votes by the legislature in two successive sessions before it can be put to a vote of the people. That's in the state constitution. The legislature of Massachusetts acted precisely in accord with the state constitution, by voting twice on the proposed amendment. The second time, they did not get enough votes for the measure to pass it along to the voters. The legislature followed the procedure laid out in the constitution, and the proposed amendment died. End of story, unless and until people in Mass. get up another petition to amend their state constitution.
 
 On the bigger question of the people voting, I think it's often inappropriate for people to vote on legislation. We elect legislators to do the work of learning about and understanding the various proposed laws that come before them. Voters are often ill informed or misinformed about specific legislation. I do not oppose initiative petitions and referenda necessarily, but I think we need to be careful not to assume that having a popular vote on a specific law will necessarily lead to a good result for the people as a whole. 
 
 For example, back in the late 1930s, during the period of great isolationist sentiment in the United States, a proposal called the Ludlow Amendment came before Congress. It would have required a popular vote before the United States could go to war! President Roosevelt understandably spoke out passionately against this amendment, and it died.
samiinh

That would be improper. If it did occur the way you describe then I have no argument with it. However, should the people initiate (initiative) an amendment or law then it would be improper for the legislature to change that law.

Incorrect. The VOTE was not unconstitutional. Merely the wording of the law. The VOTE was perfectly constitutional. 

 I put the word "vote" in quotations for a purpose.
 What is the purpose of the vote if the ONLY END PRODUCT of the vote is thrown out?
 
 
 
That is my point precisely. It is not that the issue is one that SHOULD be supported. Rather it is that the ability to VOTE should be supported.

 You're going to try to support the "ability to vote" by putting up legislation on the ballot which will be THROWN OUT of a court room?
 
 I'm sorry, but that's not "supporting" voting.
 If anything, if I were a voter who had that happen to me, I would be pretty annoyed and a little jaded. Even more reason to see my vote as NOT MATTERING...
 
 Get my point?
 
 
 
The system of checks and balances (namely the courts) is where the law is determined to be unconstitutional or not. They may yet come up with one that passes constitutional muster. I do not know.

 Let's try to put things in perspective, okay.
 I don't see anybody here saying, "Well, they want to put X on the ballot, and I think it is unconstitutional, therefore the courts should prevent X from being put on the ballot".
 
 We are explaining WHY we don't think these items should be put up to a vote in the first place.
 I mean, me personally I would LOVE to see something on the ballot revoking churches tax exempt status. But even if a majority agreed, I don't think it should be put on there because it has no point.
 
 
 
My argument is that the removal of the vote from an initiative of the people by a legislated body is outside of the checks and balances and is in itself unconstitutional.

 Who said anything about removing the vote?
 
 
 
Going through the effort is intended so that the voice of the people is heard. It is part of the system of checks and balances on the government. WE the people have a right to be heard, even if our idea is unpopular or even if the legislature does not like it.
 Huck
